bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 31, 1879

div1.p: Reed describes enlisting Indian scouts and camping in the wilderness.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, May 31, 1879
div1.p:
I know you will be
surprised to get a letter from San Car-
los, and lest you may be alarmed, I will
at once inform you- that I left Apache
on the morning of the 29th with Lt.
Gatewood and 5 men, for purpose
of enlisting twenty Indian Scouts. I
thought I had as well come along
to see the trail and the beautiful scenery
as to be sticking around Apache. We
have had a very pleasant trip -- camped
the first night on Black River in a lovely
spot- I passed away the evening in catch-
-ing the festive trout, and, at night, slept
like a top- The trail is very rough, but
I am mounted on a tip-top horse and
have no trouble. Coyle is along with
us and attends carefully to my wants.
We return, Monday morning, June 2nd &
reach Apache the 4th- The only drawback
to my coming was that I would not be
at Apache on Sunday to get my darling
little wife's sweet little letter. But
I shall expect a real nice one when
I get back. As you can imagine, my
darling, it is just “biling” hot here, right
on the Gila. The same old dust old heat, the iden-
tical old dust with its very oderiferous
odors, the same old mesquite-and the Gila
water as alkaline as you ever tasted.
I had forgotten all about hot wea-
-ther, but to-day is a powerful re-
-minder. The contrast between this and
Apache is wonderful- As the mail leaves
soon and I am so dirty -- and tired, I will
not write more now, but a real long letter
to my pretty little wife when I get
back to Apache- Best love & many
kisses for my darling wife and boy- Take
care of yourselves -- have a happy time,
and write very often to your fond and
ever devoted “hubby”,
